title: Z-Drugs for the Treatment of Sleep Disorders in Alzheimer's Disease: a Randomized, Triple-blind, Placebo-controlled Study
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine whether Zolpidem and Zoplicone are efective in the treatment of sleep disorders in Alzheimer's disease (AD)
description_detailed: Sleep disorders (SD) affects 35 to 50 percent of patients with AD. These disorders often make caring for patients at home very difficult. Zolpidem and Zoplicone are prescribed drugs for sleep disorder in AD patients.
explanation_target: Reason: The study tests Zolpidem and Zopiclone for treatment of sleep disorders in Alzheimer's disease (AD). Both drugs are sedative–hypnotic 'Z-drugs' used to treat insomnia (i.e., sleep disturbance = a neuropsychiatric symptom), so the intended effect is symptomatic improvement of sleep rather than targeting AD pathology. This maps to the 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' category.

Act — drug details: Zolpidem is a non‑benzodiazepine hypnotic (an imidazopyridine, a 'Z‑drug') that acts as a positive modulator at GABA-A (benzodiazepine) receptor sites producing sedation/hypnosis. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act — drug details: Zopiclone (often spelled this way; user wrote 'Zoplicone') is a cyclopyrrolone hypnotic that allosterically modulates GABAA receptors and is used clinically for short‑term treatment of insomnia. citeturn0search1turn0search6

Act — clinical intent: These agents are prescribed to improve sleep (symptom control) and are not disease‑modifying therapies aimed at AD pathology (e.g., amyloid or tau). citeturn0search7turn0search6

Reflect: Given the intervention (two hypnotic small molecules) and the stated purpose (treatment of sleep disorders in AD), the correct classification is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' — they are symptomatic treatments for sleep, not disease‑targeted biologics/small molecules nor cognitive enhancers.
